articles.headline: 2016 Ambitions Turn Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush Protégé, Into Rival
articles.snippet: The collision of Mr. Rubio’s and Mr. Bush’s aspirations is consuming their hometown with talk of unchecked ambition and backstabbing.
articles.abstract: The collision of Mr. Rubio’s and Mr. Bush’s aspirations is consuming their hometown with talk of unchecked ambition and backstabbing.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As Marco Rubio debated whether to run for the United States Senate in 2010, he made a pledge steeped in loyalty and deference: He would never challenge his political mentor, Jeb Bush, if the former Florida governor wanted the job himself.

articles.headline: Russian Consumers Reflect the Pinch of Economic Sanctions
articles.snippet: After years of insatiability, consumers are curbing their spending, leaving shopping centers and other retail space with high vacancies.
articles.abstract: After years of insatiability, consumers are curbing their spending, leaving shopping centers and other retail space with high vacancies.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The brand-new Avia Park is a glittering testament to the power of the Russian consumer. A panorama of white tile flooring, under a soaring, six story-tall glass roof, it is the largest mall in Europe, with 377,000 square meters of enclosed space, a 17-screen multiplex, even a 70-foot tall aquarium of tropical fish.

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank Nears Plea Deal Over Libor Manipulation
articles.snippet: The settlement, which involves federal, state and British authorities, would be one of the last cases to arise from the sweeping inquiry into manipulation of the benchmark interest rate.
articles.abstract: The settlement, which involves federal, state and British authorities, would be one of the last cases to arise from the sweeping inquiry into manipulation of the benchmark interest rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: A long-running investigation into Wall Street’s manipulation of interest rates is heading into a stark final chapter as authorities around the globe push Deutsche Bank to pay a record penalty and accept a criminal guilty plea for the unit at the center of the case.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Cooper Union Inquiry Puts Nonprofits on Notice
articles.snippet: The investigation by Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York sends a message that nonprofit organizations can no longer assume that they will receive minimal scrutiny.
articles.abstract: The investigation by Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York sends a message that nonprofit organizations can no longer assume that they will receive minimal scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what should be a ringing alarm for nonprofit boards across the country long accustomed to minimal scrutiny or accountability, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York has signaled that the laissez-faire approach to nonprofit governance is over.

articles.headline: Brought by Wild Neighbors, Deadly Bird Flu Attacks Turkey Flocks
articles.snippet: So far, under a million birds have been culled, a small part of the 240 million raised a year. But farmers must destroy entire flocks to keep the virus from spreading.
articles.abstract: So far, under a million birds have been culled, a small part of the 240 million raised a year. But farmers must destroy entire flocks to keep the virus from spreading.
articles.lead_paragraph: A virulent, deadly flu virus has hit the nation’s turkey flock, forcing culling and quarantines that are disrupting trade with various countries.

articles.headline: South Carolina Police Shooting Seen as Crime Strategy Gone Awry
articles.snippet: To many in North Charleston, aggressive policing lends a disturbing context to the shooting last weekend that has caused outrage across the country.
articles.abstract: To many in North Charleston, aggressive policing lends a disturbing context to the shooting last weekend that has caused outrage across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — It was after dark about five years ago, on a downtrodden strip of this city, when Alicia Delesline stopped trusting the police in the place where she had lived her entire life.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Schumer Is Squeezed on Various Sides Over Iran Deal
articles.snippet: Senator Charles E. Schumer’s support of a bill that could disrupt a nuclear agreement reflects the political crosscurrents he is facing on the issue.
articles.abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer’s support of a bill that could disrupt a nuclear agreement reflects the political crosscurrents he is facing on the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an event as rare as garden tomatoes ripening in January, Senator Charles E. Schumer has little to say.

articles.headline: Her Stinging Critiques Propel Young Adult Best Sellers
articles.snippet: Julie Strauss-Gabel, the Dutton publisher who has developed many of the star writers who are reshaping children’s literature, is known for her unconventional taste and stinging critiques.
articles.abstract: Julie Strauss-Gabel, the Dutton publisher who has developed many of the star writers who are reshaping children’s literature, is known for her unconventional taste and stinging critiques.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Green still vividly recalls the opening line of a stinging critique that his editor, Julie Strauss-Gabel, delivered after reading an early draft of his novel “The Fault in Our Stars.”

articles.headline: China Is Said to Use Powerful New Weapon to Censor Internet
articles.snippet: The tool allows Beijing to intercept foreign web traffic and inject malicious code, and it could have more powerful capabilities.
articles.abstract: The tool allows Beijing to intercept foreign web traffic and inject malicious code, and it could have more powerful capabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Late last month, China began flooding American websites with a barrage of Internet traffic in an apparent effort to take out services that allow China’s Internet users to view websites otherwise blocked in the country.

articles.headline: G.E. to Retreat From Finance in Post-Crisis Reorganization
articles.snippet: G.E. will sell most of its finance arm, focusing on its core industrial operations as it completes a transformation begun during the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: G.E. will sell most of its finance arm, focusing on its core industrial operations as it completes a transformation begun during the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, General Electric was happy to reap the enormous profits that arose from its finance arm as it swelled into one of the country’s biggest lenders.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Despite Federal Regulation, C.E.O.-Worker Pay Gap Data Remains Hidden
articles.snippet: An analysis of recent company reports, however, finds that the widest gap exists between the chief executives and workers of Disney, Oracle, Qualcomm and Starbucks.
articles.abstract: An analysis of recent company reports, however, finds that the widest gap exists between the chief executives and workers of Disney, Oracle, Qualcomm and Starbucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors who take the time to wade through corporate reports on what their top executives are paid are all too familiar with the problem of information overload.

articles.headline: A Murderer at 14, Then a Lifer, Now a Man Pondering a Future
articles.snippet: A landmark Supreme Court ruling has allowed juvenile murderers in some states new sentencing hearings.
articles.abstract: A landmark Supreme Court ruling has allowed juvenile murderers in some states new sentencing hearings.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Adolfo Davis admits he was a swaggering thug by the age of 14 as he roamed and dealt drugs with a South Side gang.
